brief_summary.textblock:
Colon cancer is the second most common cause of death among cancer-related deaths in
      Germany. Precancerous lesions such as adenomas can be detected efficiently by colonoscopy.
      To provide high quality in colonoscopy several quality parameters have been postulated in
      the past. The adenoma detection rate (ADR) is one of those parameters. Empirical data
      suggest that a detection rate of 20% should be demanded. Detection rates are influenced by a
      multitude of circumstances such as bowel cleanness. The facts that detection rates vary
      between colonoscopists suggests that leaning effects may also play a role. It is not known
      how ADR and other quality parameters evolve while trainees improve their skills in
      colonoscopy. The investigators postulate that a learning curve exists.  The investigators
      therefore plan to evaluate chronologically the findings of trainee colonoscopists.  A
      particular performance in detecting adenomas shall be calculated in relation to the amount
      of examinations performed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  colonoscopy performed at the Technical University Munich, Germany

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  colonoscopy performed for the purpose of polypectomy

study_pop.textblock: Endoscopy Department of a university Hospital

clinical_study.keyword: adenoma detection rate, colonoscopy, trainee, learning curve

facility.name: Medizinische Klinik und Poliklinik der Technischen Universität München

clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Training Effects on Quality Indicators in Colonoscopy: a Retrospective Study.

primary_outcome.description: While numbers of investigations rise new detection rates are calculated for each  colonoscopist.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
